reviewText:
Valhalla Hills will remind many older gamers of titles like The Settlers and Culture, which is the normal given that the development team that creates the new Viking driven experience had a hand in the creation of both those already classic titles.The entire game is built around optimization, with gamers asked to carefully control the movement of their characters and the location of their buildings to create communities that can thrive and exploit the environment around them. Valhalla Hills manages to walk a fine line between excessive complexity, which is always a temptation for the city-building genre, and a lack of variety and is suited both for long-term fans of the main mechanics and for those who discover them for the first time.

The narrative here is a pretty simple one, albeit quite funny and suitable for the temperamental gods of Norse mythology that inspired it: Odin’s in a pissy mood after his son Leko fails an “exam of the gods,” so he slams the door to Valhalla shut. Unable to rest their weary bones inside, the honorable Vikings are forced to turn to Leko — demoted to the unflattering position of “God of the Builders” — who will attempt to redeem himself by leading the heroes up the eponymous mountains. You can do this one of two ways: by opening the magic portals of Valhalla to fight the enemies within, or by appeasing the gods with tributes. And by building: doing tons and tons of building.

From the bright, cartoon landscapes to the roly poly design of the little villagers, Valhalla Hills doesn’t take itself too seriously, which is not to say the game is simplistic, shallow, or easy. In fact, there are a number of interconnected systems to monitor and master. Each level begins with a procedurally generated landmass and the player’s task is to build a thriving community that will eventually — either economically or militarily — unlock the magical portal and the bridge to Valhalla.

Like The Settlers, the player does not directly control the little Viking villagers, instead controlling where buildings are sited, the types of buildings, and the optimal paths between resources and structures. The population is autonomous and while the player may lay down a series of building sites, the workers will determine the build order. A good strategy is one that does not give the easily distracted villagers too many options.

While each level invariably requires an early build sequence that includes finding a source of raw materials and food, then crafting a workshop and tools, once the basics are established the choice becomes how to deal with the monsters or hostile warriors that spawn through or guard the portal to Valhalla. The military option requires building barracks and forging and upgrading weapons, which of course require advanced workshops and rarer materials. Less bellicose players may choose to build a series of temples to control and placate the enemy, but that path also requires an escalating series of constructions and upgrades. Both strategies are viable options and on the middle and later maps, both require a vibrant, well-managed economy.

Valhalla Hills has two basic modes: a “campaign” mode in which structures, upgrades, and game systems are introduced slowly, over a number of progressively larger maps; and an “open” mode in which all options are available from the start — as well as all monsters and other enemies. There isn’t much of a story beyond the opening cinematic that explains the premise, and while tooltips pop up every time a new structure or mechanic is introduced, neither is there a tutorial proper. Experienced players of The Settlers or other city builders can probably intuit a lot what they need to know, but it will take all players some trial and error and less than optimal results before the systems become clear.

Once you do get into the flow of this game however, you will truly be able to appreciate what it has going for it. The graphical quality, while simple, is smooth and refined, striking an unexpected balance between old-school sensibilities and modern-day sharpness. The maps are fully articulated, allowing you to move and zoom freely about their entirely and providing a hexagonal grid only when it’s appropriate, allowing a more consistent sense of immersion.

The music of Valhalla Hills is… alright. It’s soothing, adequately produced and thematically appropriate, but not memorable. Considering this title is mostly about magicing buildings into existence, large orchestral scores would’ve been strange, granted, but something a little more unique and stylish would have been nice during those times when I was hurrying up to wait.

On the point of action, there isn’t a great deal of it. Most of the fighting you will encounter is when your brave followers decide to press onward to through the next portal toward Odin’s side. At these times, and depending on how you play it, guardians may appear to challenge your vikings to prove their worth. These battles are mostly a test of your preparedness and foersight, not of your tactics or formation of units. Niko is a builder, not a fighter, and it’s at these moments that it shows the most.

This is honestly a very well built game and a pleasure to play. It’s not really all that complex or burdened with layers of technicalities of its own design. It feels inviting and wants you to have a good time poking around with your options in search discovering new features to add to your fun. But the lack of a strong tutorial system slides it to a farther end of the learning than I think the developers intended. You sort of need to have a strong grasp of RTS games like this one in order to feel confident any time soon, and that’s not the kind of thing a newcomer may want to put themselves through.

Other should-be-important details, such as how to accrue Honor, a type of passive meta-stat required by Odin for your vikings to be accepted into his kingdom, goes largely unexplained even after it becomes necessary. I cleared the first few maps being told how impressive my Honor score was with no idea what that meant, how to check it, or how I could do it again.

Valhalla Hills is all in all, a strong little RTS, with enough going on under the surface to satisfy most fans of the genre. Its style is fitting enough and the game endears itself to you and keeps you immersed. Valhalla Hills is a solid game that anyone who has ever played The Settlers will enjoy.

Intro - About  	This amazing mythological strategy game is a great game to relax to but always have that never ending rush of excitement that will never seize to wow you. A good mix of fantasy and building makes you interested throughout the game. You start out as a few Vikings on an island and must give them the resources they need to survive the wilderness and deadly foes. Build huts to allow them to get rest, build  woodcutters to supply wood, quarry's for stone, fishery and hunter for food, military for recruiting to fight off the enemies that come from the portal. Once you defeat them you gain more things to build.

Pros & Cons
++  Pros
+ Great graphics
+ Charming atmosphere
+ Enjoyable and rewarding experience
+ Plenty of options to play the way you want or to speed up process.

-- Cons
- Not enough tutorials
- Ai are almost always just running around or doing nothing
- Repedative play

Summary  	This is a great game, and is very much like a mobile game. Almost relatable to Sims or clash of clans. None the less the works great for PC and runs well and responds to everything and optomizable options and graphics to maximize performance of your game-play.
Replay-ability is strong, with you every growing and evolving population of Vikings. You learn to build different building and give more of your people to have places to work to get an efficient flow of any resource you need to keep them living and to fight.

Personal Opinion 	This was a toughy at first because I had no idea what I was doing and the tutorials did not guide me enough to fully grasp the way the game was meant to be played. Early Access Review

I used to love playing the Settlers series of games, but that kind of ended with #2 before it got a bit too military focused, and somehow lost some of the charm. So far, I've really enjoyed Valhalla Hills - it has that charm, and more. It is still early-access so I'm not sure if/how my few cons will be addressed, but here they are:

- the game starts to get a bit choppy once your island gets more populated and you have a few buildings going, but then again I'm playing on a laptop, so this may not be a huge deal
- seems to be no way to control what goes into a stockpile, which isn't a huge drawback. Each stockpile can hold multiple stacks (of up to 5-10 items, so far), but they only have a number of stacks they can hold. The basic stockpile will gladly hold 6 stacks of 5 logs, which is inconvenient if you wanted to have it store food or something

So far, those are my only two issues with the game!

Pros:
- the pacing is good. The quests slowly introduce you to each building, but it never feels like a chore, more of a guided sandbox play, which I enjoy.
- the military aspect isn't difficult so far. There's a few dudes to beat when you want to unlock the gate to finish each level (if you choose to go military route - can bypass by sacrificing goods at the altar). Some missions have baddies roaming around, but they're fairly easy to deal with and so far they do not respawn.
- the animation is good, and I enjoy watching my little dudes march around, like the old settlers games.
- there is an interesting variety of buildings so far, and I am still unlocking more, which gives good incentive to keep playing
- the graphics are really nice, even on lower settings!

Overall if you like a chill-out-and-build kind of game, this is it. Lots of fun and I am looking forward to playing more.

I've made a full video review of Valhalla hills here - https://youtu.be/tpTIx42iW2w

For those of you that prefer a written review, here it goes:

Valhalla Hills is a game very similar to the Cultures franchise and early Settlers games. In fact Valhalla Hills has been developed by Funatics Software - the same company that made these games, so it's to be expected. They've taken a well-loved pair of franchises and changed things up a little, in parts for the better - in parts for worse.

Normally games of this genre involve building up an army and destroying the opposition, In Valhalla Hills there is no specific enemy you must defeat to win the level, there is however a wide variety of enemies that are standing in the way between your settlement and your objective. To win the level in Valhalla Hills you need to enter the portal that lies at the top of the mountain and it's usually guarded pretty heavily - there’s also the option to win economically with a sacrifice (basically a bribe to the guards).

The aim of the game is to get your Vikings enough honour to enter Valhalla, which in a way makes some aspects of the game feel like a grind. Once a level is complete it's on to the next level to grind more honour! But I’m getting ahead of myself, let’s examine some game mechanics.

Production chains are pretty good actually, I'm happy with them. For the production chain of generating resources for buildings, we start with the basics - logs and quarry stone. These are good starting point for building your settlement and will be sufficient for a while. As you progress you'll need to refine these materials with another set of buildings, turning logs into planks and quarry stone into stone bricks. This is as far as the construction materials production chain goes, every structure in the game can be built with either; logs, quarry stone, planks or stone bricks. Like i said I’m happy with that, it's one step beyond what Settlers 3&4 offer but not a rabbit hole of complexity like in Cultures - a nice healthy middle ground. However this is the simplest production chain there is, it just gets more complex after that... mostly in a good way. There's a few irregularities I’ve noticed in the current build (v1.02.01) such as the kitchen, which takes the separate food items your Vikings have produced and combines them into a single unit of food (bread and meat become sandwiches) - this makes life easier for your hungry Vikings, but the nutritional value of the sandwiches is less than the sum of its parts - its wastefulness is a bit irritating!

The games AI seems to be a bit silly sometimes, they will stray too far and get attacked, after a bit of fighting back and losing health, they run off, then it seems like the AI resets and they head back to their exact previous location! The cycle of fighting, running and returning usually continues until they die. This issue is exacerbated by the inability to directly control your Vikings, they're off on their own and can't be commanded, Perhaps this is a feature, forcing you to quickly produce some troops and clear the local area - it's an RTS after all.

Speaking of the inability to control your Vikings, I get the feeling that Valhalla Hills is trapped in an identity crisis between the highly personal attachment to the Vikings that Cultures offers and the sense of distance from your people that Settlers has, where people are pretty much numbers and nothing more. It's a strange aspect to the game - You can follow your Vikings and rename them, but you can't directly control them and for the most part you have little influence on their daily activities.

Finally, if we think back to fighting up to the portal and the other main objective of the game - grinding enough honour to be worthy of Valhalla. I get a sense of what’s the point?" there's currently no campaigns (once again

reviewText:
TLDR:A pretty solid and gorgeous town management game inspired by norse mythology that, unfortunately, in terms of story leaves something to be desired.

Valhalla Hills is a real time town management game in which you play as Leko, son of Odin, who instead of being a distinguished and devoted warrior as his ancestors, prefers to spend his time building houses. Because of this Odin banishes you to live among the mortals on Earth until you regain your honour.

The game offers you two different modes to play, Classic and Open. Open mode offers a more challenging experience in which you have every building unlocked. On the other hand, Classic mode gradually increases in difficulty and unlocks more things as you play, and it is thus recommended to new players.

On Classic mode, the story starts nice and interesting but it quickly falls short and lacks any depth by only having a nicely put introductory cutscene. I still haven’t beaten the game but, from what I’ve played, there is no connection between each mission in terms of story, which I find to be rather disapointing.

Gameplay:

The game plays very simple, different colors when placing buildings, and other elements of the UI make the game somewhat intuitive and easy to understand how everything works out. Still, it has been a while since I’ve played one of these management games, and so, I must say that the tutorial and instructions that this game gives you do not really teach you some essential things, other than what some buildings do, and because of that it took me a while to learn how resource and tool distributing systems worked out.

At its core, it plays like most town management games out there, especially ones like the Settlers series. You start with a small number of vikings, which you have no direct control of,  and a handfull of resources and from there you need to figure out the best way to prosper and expand your little settlement. Usually this means building basic resources buildings such as woodcutters, toolmakers and hunters or fishermen right off the bat and, afterwards, making sure you have a steady supply of resources coming from these places in order to feed the needs of your settlers.

On each mission the objective is always the same, you have to open a portal to Valhalla. First, you need to get a unit close to the portal in order to activate it and, after that, you need to deal with the guardians that come out of these portals. This can be done in two ways, by simply killing them with your soldiers or by performing sacrifices.

Pros:Gorgeous looking visuals
Nice and cheerful soundtrack
Rewarding gameplay
Cons:Barebones story
Somewhat lacking tutorials
Repetitive levels and gameplay
Overall thoughts:

Valhalla Hills is overall a very good and pleasing title, it looks, sounds and plays great but sometimes I just wish it had something more going for it. Some of its mechanics are not well explained on the tutorial sections but after thinking for a little bit, you should start to realize how certain systems work. Eventually, you might also come across certain situations in which your vikings are wandering randomly with no idea what to do or take some time to perform a certain task, this can get somewhat infuriating but the fact that you can speed up time helps a lot. And last but by no means least, I really wish each mission was more varied other than just a bigger island to fight for and expand through and that the story was told by little bits spread across each mission, or establishing a link between them.

Verdict
If you’re a huge fan of the genre and you’re looking for another city management game with a wonderful and charming setting I’d say you check this one out. Despite its lack of story depth and somewhat repetitive levels, at its core Valhalla Hills stands strong on its own. Eitherways, I suggest waiting for a sale because I think that the current price is somewhat high for what it initially offers.

reviewText:
Product received for free

You know, people always make out the Vikings and Norse mythology in general to be a complex web of intricately-woven tales of honor, bravery, and combat. I mean, with some badasses like Odin, Thor, and Loki included in the mythology, it's pretty difficult to not be interested in their crazy tales. But.....what about the mythological figures no one talks about? Like Leko, the supposed son of Odin and the god of building? Does that not ring a bell? Well, I don't blame you, I'm pretty sure he's fictional, and he's coincidentally also the protagonist of this game.

The BreakdownValhalla Hills begins with a brief cutscene describing the story of the game. Leko, that guy I mentioned earlier, has been banished from Valhalla by his own father, Odin, because he wasn't into fighting people or something. Poor bloke! Anyway, he now sets off to regain his father's favor by being honorable through whatever means possible. And by that, I mean building stuff and fighting stuff using his little Viking minions people.

See, Valhalla Hills is a randomly-generated strategy game primarily focused on building with a side emphasis on combat. It's up to you, Leko, to open and enter the portal on each map through whatever means you choose. This may mean fighting the portal guardians using your Vikings or offering them various resources. Personally, I primarily like to offer resources because fighting can be pretty challenging. Regardless, just managing a town itself can be quite the struggle. You start with only a few Vikings, but by building a complex web of inter-connected buildings the process of maintaining a bunch of happy and healthy Vikings can be quite the struggle.

This is mainly because of the nature of the game. Valhalla Hills is not a story-based or progression-based RTS like what  you may be used to. Instead, the only story is given in one short cutscene, and the rest of the game plays out in randomly-generated maps with an arcade sort of feel to them. Each map could take anywhere from 10 minutes to an hour to complete, as it just depends on if you want to rush to enter the portal or not. However, depending on how you complete this task can alter how you play. If you want to fight your way to the portal, that can prove to be quite the ordeal because you would need to first build tools, harvest resources, make homes, make even more buildings, find a way to feed all of your Vikings, and finally make some soldiers to fight the portal guardians.

However, this is one area where I feel like the game is a little weak. It can be very, very difficult to properly balance soldiers with food production. See, soldiers eat a bunch of food even while just sitting around, which is frustrating because it requires a constant and large supply of food to them. Yet, they can't leave their military camp for some reason, so they need to have food near them. Yet, since you can't order Vikings around or move the soldiers' camp, you need to either only use them defensively or build your town far out near the portal. I know this sounds odd, and to me it really is. It basically makes the option of fighting the portal guardians basically implausible because it'd take ages to be able to build a town large enough to both place soldiers in a path all the way to the portal (which is typically far away from your starting area) and simultaneously feed them all. Sure, after a while you can unlock couriers to transport food near soldiers, but it's still a hassle, and it's frustrating trying to do a military-based run, which takes some of the fun out of that aspect of the game.

However, despite that, attempting peaceful runs is still quite fun. It's both challenging and enjoyable to try and balance the needs of non-military Vikings while keeping them busy. When you get a successful, bustling town running finally, it's a joy to just sit and watch all your Vikings go about their daily schedules. In that sense, the game can be really rewarding. Yet, there's even more rewards given to successful playstyles in the form of unlockables. And wow, this game has a ton! Only after a few hours of playing, I've unlocked a bunch of hats, buildings, environment types, and even new enemies. It definitely helps increase the replayability of the game, which is important for arcade-style games like this that caters to people who don't want to play for hours upon hours (though that is certainly an option). Though, if you do decide to keep at it and play for a while, eventually some of your Vikings will reach Valhalla itself. This is because every Viking gains honor as you play, and when they reach 100,000 they'll ascend to Valhalla. I don't think it does much, but it's still a nice addition.

And y'know, there's a lot of little intricate details that the game includes that are quite nice just to have. Each building explains what it does and there's a mini-tutorial given at the start for most of them. In addition to that, the depth of the seemingly simple economy is quite impressive. What seems like a simple progression of getting resources --> feeding vikings --> fighting stuff/collecting portal offerings is much more complicated than that. For example, if you only have 1 fisherman but have 50 Vikings, they'll eventually go hungry, causing them to work less and less until they stop working entirely, at which point you may become doomed to failure. Or, if you chop down too many trees but don't have someone who plants new ones, you'll struggle to get more wood which can collapse a large part of the town's economy. Likewise, if you hunt too many animals and don't have an animal breeder to balance the food supply, your townsfolk may starve eventually. Sure, these are all small details, but they add up to make a fun, challenging, and engaging experience.

The game may be a little complicated gameplay-wise, but it certainly isn't graphically. Everything has a simple, cartoony look to it that I think actually works quite well. The Vikings look cute (and you can give them hats!), the environments look simple but lovely, and the animations and lighting all flow in a nice, cohesive manner. In fact, I think that's the key to this game's graphical beauty: everything just flows nicely. Unreal Engine 4's lighting capabilities probably helps with that too. Yet, despite the game's aesthetic beauty, it still runs quite nicely, at least from my experience. My computer is a little old, but the game still ran very smoothly with no issues whatsoever. Sound-wise, it's what you might expect: some nice, pleasant tunes and standard sound effects for stuff like building placement. Nothing really stood out to me there.

ProsFun, challenging, and rewarding arcade-style RTS gameplay focused on city building on a randomly-generated map (though combat is an option)
Loads of replayability in the form of dozens of unlockable buildings, environment types, enemies, and hats
Beautiful graphical cohesion - a big, successful town simply looks gorgeous. Thanks Unreal Engine 4! (oh, and it runs nice too)
Steam achievements, trading cards, and cloud save support
ConsStory is largely non-existent besides a short initial cutscene
The gameplay can become somewhat repetitive after long play sessions, so it's best played in short bursts
Military-focused playstyles will suffer from a massive drain on food supplies, so be warned if you're interested in that aspect of the game
Valhalla Hills can be a highly challenging experience, especially for those who are interested in focusing on combat. Yet, it's still certainly very satisfying to play, from witnessing the gradual progression of a tiny settlement to a bustling, sprawling city of Vikings. If you're interested in arcade-style RTS gameplay that's both fun and rewarding with beautiful graphics as well, this game is definitely worth checking out.

Final Verdict: 8/10

reviewText:
Valhalla Hills is a city builder game where you play Leko, son of Odin as he tries to regain his honour back in his fathers eyes by helping mortal Vikings to build, survive and become worthy enough to enter Valhalla.

The game starts with a wonderful little story about how Leko ends up banished from Valhalla as he displays signs of creativity and enjoys building and doesn't seem to care for the traditional fighting ways of the Vikings. Odin tells him to go to Earth and become the God of the Builders and not to return. Leko, however, decides he can win a place in Valhalla with his father if he can just regain enough honor.

Valhalla Hills is reminiscent of some of the old great city builder strategy games but with it's own nice little spin. Rather than having every building unlocked for you from the start, you have to unlock them over time by regaining honor which you do by completing missions or various objectives. You do have the option to play in 'Open Mode' which allows everything to be unlocked from the start but this is significantly harder and I would not recommend this for people just starting out. The classic mode has a nice difficulty curve and teaches you what you need to know as it goes on, explaining each building or new feature to you as you unlock it preventing you from missing out on what vital buildings do.

The gameplay is pretty easy to learn if you are familiar with these types of games. You are guided through the basics like how to build, building speed, managing resources and such and each time you unlock something new, build a building for the first time or there is a new event it is explained. There is also a nice colour grid to help with placement which speeds things up a lot. Despite saying this, if you are new to this genre you might struggle. Though there is a lot that is explained to you there is also a lot that is missed out. I've played this genre for a many years but ended up making two crucial errors early on which messed up two entire missions because something very simple wasn't explained. This can become a huge problem which I'll explain further in the cons.

Each mission starts you with a few Vikings, some resources to get you started and an end portal on your map and your goal is to reach and open the end portal either killing or appeasing the guardians on the way. Your Vikings can be assigned various roles but from there onwards they will handle their duties themselves with no extra input from you (most of the time). They have basic needs as well and will require things like food and sleep with some extra needs/perks like some booze for the soldiers to keep them happy and strong. Its your job to build these things to fulfil the needs of your mortals so you can conquer each map and bring yourself closer to going home.

There is a nice selection of buildings from what I've seen so far but I feel the shape and design of the map can limit how you place them. The maps start of fairly small meaning your first few 'villages' will look fairly similar because certain buildings have to be placed near others for them to work successfully.

Despite me enjoying myself a lot so far there are some cons I would like to mention because they are noticeable. The first is that the story starts very, very strong and I was excited to play through and see more about Leko's struggles but from what I've seen there is no more to the story. The missions themselves start with no further addition to the storyline and it seems that the opening cutscene is all there is to it. This is very disappointing because the start itself was very engaging. My second issue is the fact that if you build wrong, even one building, chances are it'll mess up your entire mission. Resources are very scarce and once you have used one up you are screwed. For example, the woodcutter has a certain range where he can fell trees and there are only a certain amount of trees dotted around the map, once he destroys those trees that building is useless and I'll have to build another using logs (which can only be made in a woodcutter). If I have no logs, like I did then I'll have to demolish a building to get some as it's the only way I found to get more. Except, I had other buildings I had placed to be built and you cannot control the build priority at all so they started building those using up all my logs again. In the end I had to restart because they had all started to starve because they couldn't build the bakery. This needs to be fixed. You shouldn't require a basic material to build a building that can only be obtained from that building. This forces you to build some things in a very specific order. My last gripe I think is directly related to my previous one. You have to create each tool you need yourself rather than it being automatically created if you have the resources. This becomes a very boring thing to do over and over again but I do believe this is in place because of how limited your resources are and to stop you using up everything making tools when you need buildings first.

Overall I think Valhalla Hills is a fun game with some great features though it's lacking in any story depth. I do feel that the $30 price is too high because of this but the game is 100% worth it if it goes on sale. Another great genre edition perfect for those who are familiar with but prefer a more relaxed take on the city builder strategy genre.

Early Access Review

Good game with a bit of potential. Generally speaking it has alot of same feel and functions that you would hope to play with in a basic colony builder. I found myself falling into the familiar - yet fun - routine of trying to sort out basic problems while optimising my little village(s). Where the game started to take off more me is in the exploration you find yourself doing on maps and the constant randomness of the maps you play on. Because of the constant change I feel like trying map after map so it gets high marks for replayability at this time.
Downsides at the moment - seeing as I'm reviewing this in early access - is that the 'end game' is pretty empty at this point. The few items like iron weapons and gold as an example are a nice perk for your warriors but certainly not necessary as you can just chug mead like a good viking and just have an uber army easily. The Kitchen - which  requires a solid amount of infrastructure to produce - is something that I enjoy from other games like Anno 2070 where you try to build up resources to have a cool pay off at the end. The problem is that at the moment this is one item - and it barely works even if you throw hordes of resources at it - which I found aggravating for an 'end game' item.
Game is a great deal of fun the first 8-10 hrs. - then I began to imagine how modding and an increase items and building to construct would really help the game. The gameplay is fun along the lines of Banished but without the community and fun items to build at the moment.
Would recommend - but it will need to be taken as a 8-10 hr. game in early access.

Early Access Review

Valhalla Hills, is a fun building simulation game, where we help our fellow abandoned vikings from Asgard's gates, and fighting our way to a portal to access the kingdom.

You will be throwed straight away to take care of a bunch of fallen vikings from the sky and settle a new home at mountains.  You have the mind of a home-builder, to give your fellow drunken friends a roof over their heads, where you will have the skills to build Production, Logistics and combat. These three functions will allow you to build houses, military, woodcutters etc.  Every work will be assigned automatically to a viking, where we can expand it's tools. By putting down either a home, or any kind of work related, the current building can be placed on the map, but be aware, that the map will limit you for space and offers green, for less rescources needed, yellow, for more. When you have finished building and designing your home, then we are taking the next step. A army to defend and attack the portal, you will face Guardians that will stop every single viking. By killing them, wins the current game. After that, you have a option to either move on and get new buildings or either continue with the current home you made.

Overall game design, the game looks stunning with it's use of UE4 engine. The design of vikings and atsmophere really gives the feeling of it's time, where you want to keep playing. The interface is friendly and extremely simple. Unfortunately this game does not offer any kind of Co-op / Multiplayer which i could imagine bring more fun to the games content.

If you like taking care of fallen vikings, be the builder and brain to recover drunk energy to fight the guardians and return to Asgard's gates, then this game is definitely for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I had to summarize Valhalla Hills, I'd say it is Cultures, a game from 2000, with a lot less micromanagement, but sadly also loosing some of its depth. Valhalla Hills doesn't has a story-mode aside from the short story of being the cast out son of Odin who needs to build his way back to Valhalla. Instead, you play on randomly generated maps where you start at the foot of a mountain. You have to build a base and prepare your vikings to open a portal at the top of the mountain to advance to the next map. The units are vikings you cannot control directly. If you encounter a map you can't win or you don't want to play, you can simply generate a new map, but you loose the progress of the current one.

New buildings, biomes and stronger enemies are unlocked while playing by a kind of achievement system. On one side it gives the the game some progression and it doesn't bombard you with too much information, on the other side, the beginning is too easy and feels repetitive. It takes around 6-8 hours to unlock everything, but I hope the developer will add more content because it gets quite repetitive after 4 hours.

As I've mentioned above, the building part is quite nice, but the victory condition requires some more polish. After building the first few buildings to get building materials and food, you can assemble a little military force and start fighting your way through to the portal. the portal is usually guarded by several enemies that can either be killed, or you can sacrifice materials to bribe them. Sadly, the difficulty to produce these materials varies wildly. I had a few games in a row where I had to sacrifice water and plain old wood, very basic materials to bribe the strongest enemies. Other times I had to produce high quality products to bribe weak enemies, so fighting was much easier. The developer should put some more work into this ending to make it more satisfying for the player. Building a large and expensive monument could be a solution.

The mentioned fighting system isn't very fun either as it is partly luck. each unit does a fix value of damage to the enemy, but sadly you can't tell your units whom to fight first. The difference between winning and loosing a battle isn't preparation and tactics, but the luck of which enemy gets attacked by your stubborn vikings first, and if the enemies focus your vikings or if they spread their attacks over your units. Even worse: it can happen that a viking gets hungry on the way to war and wanders off to get food or sleep while the other are fighting. This makes fighting kind of luck based, something I don't really like in a building game. Some general orders for your vikings would be helpful.

The game uses the Unreal 4 engine to produce a good art style.The game is held in a cartoon style with exaggerated animations that can easily create the aquarium effect well known from games of the settler series or city-builder games. Sometimes you just want to take a moment and watch your vikings while they work... typically German, I know. The game looks especially nice during night time when all the different houses have torches in front of their door. The sound is good and fits the setting, yet nothing special.

All in all, Valhalla Hills show a lot of promise in it's early stage. It still needs a lot of work, but the team has a lot of knowledge in building games and a strong publisher covering their back. I look forward to seeing new content. If you like the genre, it is already worth a purchase.

So, I bought this to play on my Mac. Almost immediately requested a Steam refund.

The touchpad doesn't work at all: as soon as I touch it at all, the viewport zooms in as far as it can, and then I cannot zoom out at all. (Unplayable.)

reviewText:
Hija,

I am still pondering about this game, there are plenty of things I like, as a old Settlers 1 2 3 and 4 player it is very easy to see the influence of those games in Valhalla Hills. It also has Culture's in it but I don't remember enough about the game to really see this part of it in this game.

The graphical style fits the game, its relaxed yet has a lot of atmosphere, it has most of the buildings you expect. Woodcutters, Sawmills, Wheat farms, Mills, Bakery's etc. There is also the military side of the game but here I start to feel the lack of the game.

You see, I never feel like I am in any kind of trouble, if you played the old settlers, you knew that at some point the AI would swarm you and destroy you quite easy if you are to laid back.
In this game, there are no Romans or Vikings or Egyptians, just beings that live underground and come out of it, starts building towers (without units in it..) and then spread its influence across the map, but it never really attacks, I never ever build a guard tower, 9 military units suplied by gold to increase damage and brew to increase health is enough to win the map.

The AI of your own Vikings aren't that clever either, they don't spread goods around when your start to build a lot of buildings, quite often I see a gold mine have 5 ores, yet my smelters aren't full. The couriers that they give a tip for, to use when the map gets larger and more populated, are very bad at actually moving goods around. This with the fact of some key functions, like being able to manually say what items to store in storage buildings doesn't help, and you end up with 20 sticks in it, which aren't that usefull..
Forresters like to start planting trees not near the building itself but far away for some reason, and you can't put where they work yourself like you could in the old settlers.

All in all its fun and yet frustrating, its not bad but not good either. Perhaps, future DLC will add or improve. So while I recommend it, I would say a 6/10.
